Overview: Diabetes is primarily caused by the body's inability to use insulin effectively or produce enough insulin. Genetic factors also play a significant role.
Common symptoms include excessive thirst, hunger, frequent urination, and unexplained weight loss.
Managing diabetes often requires insulin injections and lifestyle changes, such as diet and exercise.
Hypertension, or high blood pressure, can result from dietary factors, obesity, or genetic predisposition.
Symptoms often include headaches, blurred vision, and shortness of breath, but it can also be asymptomatic.
Treatment typically involves medication to lower blood pressure and lifestyle modifications like diet and exercise.
Depression can be caused by a variety of factors including genetic predisposition and life events such as trauma or chronic stress.
Symptoms include a persistent feeling of sadness, loss of interest in activities, changes in appetite, and sleep disturbances.
Treatment typically involves psychotherapy, medication, or a combination of both. Lifestyle changes and support groups can also be beneficial.

Overview: Conditions like heart disease are often caused by lifestyle factors and can lead to serious health issues like heart attacks and stroke.
Symptoms can range from chest pain and shortness of breath to fatigue and irregular heartbeat.
Treatment often involves lifestyle changes, medication, and in some cases, surgery.
